newsitem.title: USA: Progress made in tobacco talks - NYT.
newsitem.headline: Progress made in tobacco talks - NYT.

text.p: Negotiators in the tobacco talks were making progress on several key regulatory and legal issues, the New York Times said on Friday.
The Times said that although some progress has been made, several significant hurdles remain.

Quoting unnamed sources close to the talks, the paper said one area of agreement reached by negotiators involved a substantial penalty that cigarette makers would pay if smoking by young people was not reduced by 50 percent after seven years.

Still unresolved, however, was the issue of the size of any settlement fund to compensate ill smokers, their survivors and the 29 states that have sued the tobacco industry to recover Medicaid money spent on smoking-related claims, the report said.
"We feel that we have made good progress," Mississippi Attorney General Michael Moore told the Times. Moore is a principal architect of the talks.
